p.hi: CHrist did commit at his departure hence, the te≈øtimony of that truth, for which he died, and the conuer≈øion of the Nations to the beleefe in him, to the true church of God, which then ≈øtoode principally, and almo≈øt onely in the per≈øons of the Apo≈øtles and a fewe more, that by their preachings, and tho≈øe afterward of their calling, the Chri≈øtian religion might be planted in all Nations, beginning at Ieru≈øalem, and ≈øo proceeding to the coa≈øtes and corners of the earth.

div.head: AN ANSVVERE TO THE PROPOSITION.
div.p:
I Graunt that our Sauiour Chri≈øt, at his departure hence, commaunded his Apo≈øtles as principal members of his Church, though not the greate≈øt part of it, to preach the doctrine which he confirmed by his death vnto all nations, beginning at Ieru≈øalem, and ≈øo forth according to his ≈øaying: Goe therefore and teach all Nations baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Sonne, and of the holy Gho≈øt: Teaching them to ob≈øerue all thinges what ≈øo euer I haue commaunded you. Matth. 28. Whereuppon I chalenge the Papi≈øt, that if he be able to proue that the doctrine of poperie is all that trueth, and nothing but that trueth, for
which Chri≈øt dyed, and which he commaunded the Apo≈øtles to teach, I will acknowledge the popi≈øh church to be the Church of Chri≈øt.

div.head: The fir≈øt article conteyneth 3. demandes.
1 Fir≈øt I aske of the prote≈øtant what Church that was, which conuerted all the≈øe cuntries that be now Chri≈øtian, to the faith of Chri≈øt?
div.p: IF you meane by Chri≈øtians, true Chri≈øtians, and by the faith of Chri≈øt, the true faith of Chri≈øt, I an≈øwere: only the true Church of Chri≈øt, hath had the worde of God and ≈øacraments, as meanes which God v≈øeth, to ≈øubdue al nations vnto the obedience of the faith, as was the primitiue Church of the Apo≈øtles, which hath continued vnto this daye by ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, not of per≈øonnes, and places, but of faith and truth, wherefore if the Papi≈øt can proue, that we holde not the ≈øame faith and trueth, vnto which the Apo≈øtles conuerted the nations, we refu≈øe to be called the Church or Congregation of Chri≈øt.

But if by Chri≈øtians and Chri≈øtian faith, you meane all them that profe≈ø≈øe the name of Chri≈øt, in the whole worlde, I aun≈øwere, that the true Church of Chri≈øt, did not conuert them all, for in Aethiopia, there are yet people, conuerted by the fal≈øe apo≈øtles, which taught circumci≈øion, and ob≈øeruation of the lawe, in which here≈øie they continue vnto this day, and it is manife≈øt by all hi≈øtories, that the nations of the Alanes, Gothes, and Vandales, were fir≈øt conuerted by the Arrians.

div.head: 2 And let him ≈øhew vnto me, that euer his Church conuerted any people, or lande in the earth, from Idolatrie, or Gentility, or Iudai≈øme, to the true Religion of Chri≈øt, or that this his fayth was taught to any Nation in ≈øteede of true Chri≈øtianity.
div.p:
VVE are members of that Church, which conuerted all landes in the earth that are conuerted, from Idolatry,
Gentility, Iudai≈øme, or here≈øie, to the true Religion of Chri≈øt, and we affirme that the Apo≈øtles taught none other faith in ≈øteede of true Chri≈øtiantie, but that which we hold, as we are readie to proue by the worde of God: And at this daye the mo≈øt parte of Europe, is conuerted from Idolatrie, here≈øie, and Antichri≈øtianitie, vnto the ≈øame true faith, that we mainteine, as in England, Scotland, Ireland, France, Germany, Denmarke, Suetia, Bohemia, Polonia, by publike authoritie, in Spaigne, and Italie, a great numbre vnder per≈øecution and tyrannie. Al≈øo of the Iewes, no ≈ømall numbre are conuerted to our religion, ≈øince the ri≈øing vp of the Go≈øpell in our dayes.

div.head: 3 Or any Church, but the common Catholike Church to haue don that, and I recant.
div.p:
BEcau≈øe you meane by the common Catholike, not the true Catholike, but the popi≈øh church: Fir≈øt I denie that euer the popi≈øh church conuerted any people, to the true faith. Secondly, I denie that the popi≈øh church hath conuerted all nations, to the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt: For, it is ≈øhewed before, that the fal≈øe Apo≈øtles, and Arians, conuerted ≈øome nations to the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtes name, but yet to fal≈øe religion, And it is al≈øo manife≈øt by hi≈øtories, that the Grecians, whome the papi≈øtes counte no parte of their church, but ≈øchi≈ømatikes, conuerted the Mo≈øcouites fir≈øt of all, vnto the profe≈ø≈øion of the name of Chri≈øt, which yet continue in their religion, being neither the true faith, nor yet popi≈øh religion. the true doctrine of the Apo≈øtles, is that which conuerted all nations to true religion, and that the popi≈øh church, hath not conuerted any people to true religion, nor all people to the profe≈ø≈øion of the name of Chri≈øt, this chalenger, who≈øoeuer he be, do the recant.

div.head: The ≈øecond article conteyneth 4. demandes.

div.p: I Aun≈øwere, it was the Church of Chri≈øt, and not the Popi≈øh church, which hath commended the bookes of holy Scripture, to be beleued of all true Chri≈øtians where ≈øoeuer they be, although it be the office of the holy Gho≈øt, to open the hartes of men, and to forme them that they may beleue the ≈øcripture to be true, like as it is the office of the ≈øcripture or worde of God, to trie and examine, whether it be the ≈øpirite of God that per≈øwadeth vs to beleue any thing, ≈øo the ≈øpirite beareth witne≈ø≈øe to the worde and the worde to the ≈øpirite. div.head: 2 VVhat Church hath had the di≈øcerning & ≈øeuering of them from other writinges of all ≈øortes?
div.p: THe Church of Chri≈øt, hath not an ab≈øolute authority to allow or refu≈øe bookes of the ≈øcripture, but a iudgment to di≈øcerne true writinge from counterfaicts, & the word of God, of infallible verity, from ye writing of men, which might erre, & this iudgement ≈øhe hath, not of her ≈øelfe, but of the holy Gho≈øt: as for the popi≈øh Church, it can not be ≈øaid to haue this iudgemeÃÑt of di≈øcerning the ≈øcripture of God from other writings, not only becau≈øe ≈øhe is ≈øo blind that ≈øhe can not di≈øcerne betwene ye Canonical bookes of the ≈øcripture, from the Apocrypha writings, as appereth by receauing the bookes of the Machabees, Eccle≈øia≈øticus, &c. to be of equall authoritie with ye bookes of the Law, P≈øalmes, &c. but al≈øo becau≈øe ≈øhe is ≈øo pre≈øumptuous, as to compel men to beleue, that Cu≈øtomes, and traditions, writinges of doctors, decrees of Popes, and Councells, are equall with the authoritie of God his worde, yea are of force, to alter and change the lawe of God, and the in≈øtitution of Chri≈øt, ≈øet forth vnto vs in ye ≈øcripture.
